name: Dream Of Mirror Online
description: Behold an anime-themed land of wonders, friendship and skill, shrouded in the mysteries of an ancient world yours to explore. Forge relationships and find new friends, take up a job, or soar through the majestic skies as you rediscover a social MMORPG beloved by many around the world!
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows XP/Vista/2000/98 Processor: 1000 Mhz Intel P3 or equivalent Memory: 512 MB RAM Graphics: GeForce2 MX/Radeon 7500 or equivalent 64mb VGA Card DirectX: Version 9.0c Storage: 2 GB available space
recommended_requirements: OS: Windows XP/Vista/2000/98 Processor: Pentium 4 2.0 GHz or greater Memory: 2 GB RAM Graphics: GeForce FX/AMD Radeon 9600 or higher DirectX: Version 9.0c Network: Broadband Internet connection Storage: 2 GB available space

reviews.review_text: 7 years later and I still love this game! Fair warning though; this is not your typical hack'n'slash mmo. Leveling here is not quick (unless you grind endlessly like a mad man every single day)  DoMo is very casual and social. You can level up by either doing quests or grinding (but mostly grinding). There is no dungeons in this game. I repeat, there is no dungeons! (although there are raids for guilds)  Don't feel like leveling today? It's okay, DoMo still has something for you!  Hunt for recipes,  Complete treasure maps, Conquer the market with your mysterious stall, Join PvP matches at the arena, You can even pet play in the Guild Cottage.  That's right, there's an actual Guild Cottage Where you can hang out and access your bank amongst many other things.   I've tried 23 other mmos this year and DoMo still beats them all for me, So come give it a shot!  It's free~

ok first and for most yes this is a very very outdated game, it has it quirks and pet peeves to many people but to those who are trully loyal to this game(I'm looking at my fellow domo players from AGE and GT servers) who stuck around love this game and what it means to use now many of you out there are complaining oh it sucks it nothing like today games, it has terrible interface, some the mechanics of the game suck, well as a veteran player yes they do but we grit our teeth and lived with it till domo closed long ago and it those flaws those quirks and pet peeves we learned to get around or found funny aside from that the game a social game, interact with other players make jokes coversate role play learn to love the simpler things in gaming, sure this game isnt good looking like others but it has aged well for being this old and if anything if it succeeds and gets more support they may even give it an overhaul  so   pros: -multi-class system: lets you pick what you want and lets your freely change  -relationship system: a good social aspect of the game being in a teacher/student, best friends, or lovers means a lot of benefits from buffs to items of even helping your guild look into it  -flying: ok there going to be a con for this later; regardless flying in this game means a lot of traveling cut down on the open world maps  -titles: for the completionist there a lot of titles with a good portion having various effects; so for the completionist happy hunting  -pets: another 2 sided one, ok pets are nice they can be helpful and later on be used to fly with or mount into battle  -graphics: for this being an old OLD game the cell shaded look aged well  cons:  -age: the game old enough said it just old  -coding: now this game back in my days was nortorious for crashing randomly, and getting stuck on stairs(this was hilarious when you had that one friend running from mobs and getting caught)  -gathering: ok this is a hefty topic ok gathering in this game takes time this where most veterans go 2 ways either get a forger fairy to gather for you OR set up a second account to farm the matriels for you now after gathering you had a 20 to 1 ratio for refining to a crafting matriel this can actually be improved on easily for the none cash shop using players a simple rework of the ratios  -class attribute and skill points: ok so the game allows you to reset all your skills and stat points till 15 this is actually a bit of an issue now if it was say to 20-25 I can see this would allow people to test the class more see if it fits them rather then after 15 being 'oh snap I dont like this set up and I cant change' believe me I been there I know a lot of people been there we all suffered that(you're not alone)  -flying: again great for traveling downside to land you need find a landing pad and you cant use it in public dungeons and you need a weapon of your class or the trainer sword  -pets: here's the cons you need to actually maintain loyalty and the higher the level pet the longer it takes trust me I had many capped pets in the old AGE server took me least 5 hours I know that pain  -armor breaking: ok this is one those annoying parts we had to grit our teeth and bare with all armors no matter your evasion no matter your defense it will break eventually and even more painful it going to lose max durability with each repair; again another simple fix softstar can fix by making max durability reduction a chance occurance; and still if you're a alchemist you can remedy this easily by making new sets  neutral:  -crafting: ok this will take some time to build up to but once you're there you'll be fine it all about patience and persistance       summary: this game to veterans is memory lane; to new comers it one of patience and learning how to work around a lot of quirks of this game, dont get mad and rage quit right away play til you hit 30 or 40 then decide only thing you lose is time(and money if you put any coin in) this is an old game yes we all know if you're having a hard time go to broadcast chat or ask someone around for help and advice dont be afraid to ask anyone, I played this from my sophmore year to graduation(almost didnt past it was that fun to play back then) just give it a try if you dont like it dont rage just move on, it not for everyone and no one will be the wiser if you just walk away so just enjoy what you like in DOMO maybe it'll lead to other things

I started playing DoMO in 2008. Since it's rerelease I've logged in over 100 days of game play, I love DoMO and no other game play compares. The endless combinations of jobs and sub jobs is fantastic. Like most MMOs there are parts where it's grindy and parts where levels fly bye. The graphics aren't as realistic as other games, but the cartoonishness adds to the games character and charm. With hundreds, even, thousands, of costume pieces and combinations, you can easily make your character your own. Make friends, join a guild, never have to choose 1 job ever again!  Dream of Mirror Online is the MMO for you.

Glad this game got a second chance, hopefully this time around DOMO won't be shut down and removed - like it happened back in the day when Aeria was hosting it.   All you nostalgic people out there that used to play DOMO you'll prolly either come back or move on. The new peeps won't be too ecstatic about it, well who care's. I enjoy the game fully, its terrific. Especially if you're into anime styled MMO's, like I am.

I played this back in '11, so I was late to the party, but I can safely say it's among my favorite MMOs.  If you don't have friends to play with and aren't looking to socialize with this game's playerbase, then this game isn't for you -- solo play becomes a grindy, arduous chore and all but the most dedicated MMO players will grow bored before hitting Lv. 20, and oftentimes the sluggish feeling is only mitigated by purchases from the currently-lackluster Item Mall.  If you're a socialite and tend to stick around to play with friends and meet new ones, then you'll be all over this game for sure. Partying up for a good grind is much more enjoyable -- relaxing between punching sessions nets some fun conversations and memorable moments, and joining a guild makes for the opportunity to establish real connections with some of these people. While the in-game social structure isn't used quite as much as it was intended (to my knowledge), it certainly lives up to its promise of emphasis on social interaction.

Solid game play progression with fair difficulty curve. Friendly community (with its fair share of bad apples)- generally speaking, if you ask questions in the 'broadcasting channel', which broadcasts across the entire map to all players, multiple people will answer your question *expect at least 1 troll response. Tutorial is short and barely covers the basics. A once unique job system, copied over time (this game is over 10 years old, brought back from the dead) that allows 14 different classes to be leveled INDIVIDUALLY, while also utilizing the power you gained with the 'sub skills'. I.E. you level your doctor to 30, you can switch to your level 10 mercenary and opt to keep your healing skills. Each job class (minus commoner) has a variety in how you play it. Martial artist can use staff attacks or gloves, Mecenary can use a spear (team play) or an axe + shield (solo play), etc.  Decent late game available currently, not all that is available, but a good variety to keep players interested. If you are willing to look past the incredibly dated graphics of the 'gamecube era' of games (early 2000's) you are in for a treat!  Very solid game that only recently got revived, and for good reason. Definitely worth looking into if you want a solid Free to Play MMORPG with light Pay to Win aspects. Pets, slight armor / weapon upgrades (double gold), experience and item drop rate boosters are some of the things in the item mall; the Pay to Win aspect is very minimal at the given moment.  Solid game for casual or hardcore gamers.

This game brings back a lot of fond memories. I won't deny that the people who love this game very clearly grew up with it as I did, and it was a shame that Aeria cancelled publishing it before we could fully enjoy it.   HOWEVER.   The memories I have of this game are a prime example of the term 'nostalgia blinded'. I was overjoyed to hear that someone had began publishing the game again, and eagerly downloaded it. Needless to say, I only downloaded the steam version afterwards to write this review. As the game is nothing I remembered it to be.  The UI and controls are crazy asinine and clearly haven't been updated since its original publication many years ago. The class system, while diverse, has lots of really dumb out-of-the-way requirements for getting certain classes. The stat system is impossible to figure out before you hit the cap that allows for free resets on your own, hence why the game has to link to the damned wiki in the first place, and even then you're not gonna be 100% happy with your stat build.   The story is a product of its time, quickly written and thrown in just for the sake of saying it has one. And the gameplay consists of near nothing but quests containing 'Kill this thing until you're ready to get the quest where you kill its palette-swaps. Maybe get a party and kill a boss or two.'   As much as I loved DOMO back in the day, playing it now makes me firmly believe that it should have stayed dead.

So, I played this game for half an hour; after playing it way back in the day. A lot has changed since then; unfortunately games like this have not. In addition to the very stiff controls {I'm not talking movement which can be changed in the Options with the WASD toggle}; I found that the game pace was very slow. So I settled on playing through what I thought was a good pace, following quests; killing level equivalent monsters; etc. I only found out that this is not the best way to level to the point of acquiring your first job and in fact adds on another 30-40 minutes of un-necessary exposition and needless gameplay. But that can be overlooked; because let's face it, no game company wants their games considered to be fast paced anymore.    But that wasn't what bothered me; what actually bothered me was the somewhat estranged fact that despite having a Quest Tracker up; none of the quests I had gotten would add or could be added to it. It was just a big ol' block. So I constantly have to open my Map just to see where I am going next. I even paid attention to the information the NPCs stated.    I also noticed the majority of the models had yet to be updated to what DOMO was like just before the shut down. So, if anything; this could be called what DOMO was a good year before it actually ended. Also, does anyone else find it odd that the text is some sort of binary but doesn't fit on most of the bars and descriptions; or it is just me?

I don't have a full hour yet, but I decided to go ahead and make a review because of one thing regarding this game:  The initial impression. Read the whole thing before you go 'well, what do you know, with only one hour?'  Upon starting the game up, it tells you to link your account with their site. That's fine, whatever. The big issue is the fact that the game's resolution is automatically set at a messed up number (couldn't tell you what one, exactly), and you can't change this, until you get in game. In fact, there are no options settings at all at the inital menu, and they are only visible once you get in game.  Besides that point, there is also the fact that the music, for whatever reason, is automatically muted, and you have to turn this on as well. Even after the music is turned on, it's still kinda wonky, and doesn't loop very often, so you'll have a thirty-second period of music, then another few minutes of silence (not counting the attacking sound effects).  Character creation is a joke, and I don't know if this was done the way it was AS a joke, or if they weren't finished with it, and never got around to fixing it. You can give your character a large head, and make them taller, shorter, thinner, or fatter. You then have a handful of hairstyles and even less hair colors to pick from. The races seemed interesting, but not too terribly to get me to pick something besides human.  While on the subject of characters, the motions are kinda weird. They don't seem broken, but they don't seem too fluid from time to time. The motions themselves are just weird, and it's hard to explain them without seeing them. Basically, they seem a little bit under par for the course, in regards to them.  Humor is kinda bland. The game tries to throw it in, but it's too forced.   Now, some long term player might say 'it gets better at level 15/20/30!' and that may be so, but when you're looking at this game, which is still free of course, against something that did the same thing, such as Mabinogi or Dragon Nest, and did it better, why would you waste your time on this?   The game is rather outdated, that's a given, but there is still a lot about the game that would have been pretty poor, even when it was released.   So, if you're looking for an anime MMORPG (or any new MMORPG for that matter), I wouldn't look here, unless something shifts in the game's favor.

I'm so glad that Aeria has decided to bring back an old favorite of mine and better yet release it on Steam! Now, this review is purely bias and I do not condone anybody that hasn't played this game to necessarily try it. The great parts of this game involve community interaction and, yes, roleplaying. This game has a very simple yet complex class system that is utilized well in the later levels, a pet system that is my absolute favorite, and an easier dungeon type setting makes the anime themed world seem real. However, gameplay is very boring compared the newer action MMORPG's and paid items are quite expensive and can be a tad p2w but nonetheless I'm going to be playing this game again to relive my old memories. I hope this review can help anybody looking to try the game.

This game is all right. I have mixed feelings in the review. I am going to say 'yes' for the game itself but warn players that there is hardly any support for this game.   I hate to say this... You can tell this game is slowly dying. You can kind've tell. That's not to say there isn't an active playerbase and the community seems friendly. It has great potential if it was taken better care of, though.   The controls are a bit clunky and the interface/graphics show it's age. The English translation is so-so. The nice feature of this game is that you can switch Professions at any time. You can have a primary and a secondary Profession at any time, mixing skills to create a unique style of gameplay that could match your style. Yet, it takes hours to collect any crafting items.  The flying system only lets you land in certain places, and I just... I had a horrible time with it.   I did like this game and played for a bit, but I can honestly say I have trouble wanting to play a game that has pretty much NO technical support. Good luck trying to contact the company in charge of this game... their forums are dead. But I know I can say I gave this game a fair try.

The problem with most MMOs is they expect you to, you know, have friends and ♥♥♥♥.  I have exactly ONE friend, and that friend, no matter how much I beg, refuses to play any games with me.  I can not recommend a game that expects you to be the world's most popular rock star, surrounded by groupies who just want to do everything that you do all the time.  Maybe if you're the world's most popular rock star, surrounded by groupies who just fawn over everything you do, and imitate you endlessly, you'll enjoy this game. Otherwise, forget it. It's fun for a while, but then the difficulty really ramps up on the expectation that you'll develop a crowd of followers that will play it with you, or you will die. ALOT.  Wait ... There's another demographic that would enjoy this game, too, and that's not popular rock stars.  That would be the masochists. You know the ones. The ones who complain if they don't die a bazillion times trying to kill that first mob they encounter, the game's 'too easy.'  Well, good news! If you like games where you die over and over and over and over and over again, this game might be for you! Sure, you'll be reaching level 10 or level 15 or something before it starts to do it, so it might be a bit of a slow start. But once you get there, you'll love it!

I love this game, don't agree with all the choices Suba Games have made in regards to the Item Mall, but the game itself is great and the class system is simply the best I've ever seen, most people negatively rating the game are either doing so because they have high standards of an old ♥♥♥ game, or because they lack the ability to play an MMO that doesn't baby you from the start.  Edit: Changed to negative review  Game is under very bad management, has become nothing but a money hungry cash grab and deserves to die and burn in the history of good games gone horrible. do not play this game under the current company.
